channel.title: Fan speed question
channel.description:
What happens if the fan in a computer runs at 3000RPM?
3000RPM is 50Hz, the same frequency as mains voltage in the uk. Does freaky resonance occur and explode the internet?
ps this question is serious.

item.title: Fan speed question
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

My hardware doesn’t allow me to change the speed of a fan manually, I was just wondering sorry…

Read full topic

item.title: Fan speed question
item.dc:creator: @Unlimited1 .Unlimited
item.description:
@Unlimited1 wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:12, topic:317376”][quote author=sanga282 link=topic=413911.msg3050392#msg3050392 date=1260048243]
well there are theories of resonation that people have tested, such as a small device that could bring down a bridge by just resonating at its natural frequency but its bs its not catastrophic things although there can be a noticeable movement
[/quote]
mythbusters proved it[/quote]

Nikola Tesla invented a machine that when attached to an object and tuned to vibrate at a certain frequency, can cause an earthquake-like effect on the object it is attached to.

busted

The MythBusters built several variations of Tesla’s pneumatic “earthquake machine” using modified jackhammers, as well as a specially designed computer-controlled electromagnetic linear actuator made by Grant. Small scale tests on metal bars were mixed, with the modified tools performing poorly while the more finely-tunable actuator produced significant vibrations in the bar. A scale test with a model of Tesla’s lab and miniature motor failed to produce any noticeable result. Finally, a large scale test using an actual bridge was attempted. The MythBusters attached the resonator to the side of a large truss bridge to see whether the entire bridge would be shaken. While the resonator did match the bridge’s frequency and produce a vibration noticeable 100 ft away, it was not strong enough to be considered an earthquake. With the combination of the lack of spectacular results and Tesla’s tendency to exaggerate his accomplishments at the time of publication, the MythBusters declared the myth busted.

If you want to know so bad just test it.

Read full topic

My physics teacher must have been lying then
[/quote]

item.title: Fan speed question
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

Shut up you twat I’m not trolling, I was questioning something my teacher insisted was fact. He said that they have to make sure that with electronics that need fan cooling, the frequency of the fan does not equal the frequency of the power so it doesn’t resonate and damage the appliance. I didn’t believe it so I googled it and asked here, is there something wrong with that?

You also seem to think I’m talking about the sheer speed of the fan, which I’m not.

Read full topic

inertia:

What happens if the fan in a computer runs at 3000RPM?

It makes a loud noise.

inertia:

3000RPM is 50Hz, the same frequency as mains voltage in the uk. Does freaky resonance occur and explode the internet?

My fan which runs over 3000rpm at load has not accidentally the internet.

Hi Troll

item.description:

YEAH IT DOES!! Just like how you can give yourself aids. =P
